risinfo.chaptertitle: 3. Presenting Problem, History of Presenting Problem, and Social History

sect1.title: Referral Question and Presenting Problem
sect1.para: The first stage of the interview is to explore the presenting problem (sometimes called the chief complaint), which involves clarifying the referral question and understanding the client’s reason for seeking an evaluation. At this stage, the clinician should focus on the present effects of the problem. The client’s biopsychosocial history will be collected later in the evaluation process.

sect2.title: The Referral Question and Secret Questions
sect2.para: Referral question themes and presenting problem sample interview questions

entry.para: Referral question themes
Examples of common referral questions
Diagnostic clarity
• Is the client or referring provider seeking assessment or treatment for a specific diagnosis?
Treatment planning
• If the client meets criteria for [diagnosis x], what are the best practices for treatment?
Vulnerabilities
• What are the client’s subjective or objective deficits?
• How do vulnerabilities explain the client’s difficulties meeting goals and fulfilling expectations?
Strengths
• What are the clients’ strengths?
• What aspects of the client would be helpful in managing the problem?
Contributing factors and outcomes of the problem
• How did this problem arise? Where did it come from?
• Under what conditions does the problem improve or get worse?
Referral and secret questions
• What is going on that led you to make this appointment? Why seek help now?
• What are your goals for our meeting today?
• What do you hope to hear when this evaluation is all done?
• What is the thing you are most afraid you will hear when I give you the results of this assessment?
Presenting problem: General symptoms
• What symptoms cause you the most difficulty?
• Is there one issue or symptom that is the worst for you?
Presenting problem: Physical/somatic symptoms
• What physical symptoms currently cause you trouble (even if you think they may not be related to the presenting concern), for example, pain, cardiovascular, or gastrointestinal problems?
Presenting problem: Vegetative symptoms
• Do you have difficulties with sleep, appetite or weight changes, tiredness or excessive energy, or your libido or interest in sexual activity?
Presenting problem: Cognitive symptoms
• Do you have difficulties with your thinking ability, such as with concentration, attention, memory, or ability to engage in complex tasks?
• What have other people said about your memory or ability to focus?
Presenting problem: Other psychological symptoms
• What is your mood like on a typical day? Does it remain stable or fluctuate?
• Do you have other concerns with your emotions or mood that you have not yet shared?
Presenting problem: Functional symptoms
• What difficulties has this problem caused for you (at work, socially, in relationships, self-care, etc.)?
• How much discomfort do your symptoms cause you?
• In what ways do your mental health symptoms make it harder for you to care for yourself? (e. g., hygiene, grooming, dressing, eating, housework, living independently, etc.)?
• Do you have any difficulty completing complex day-to-day tasks, such as grocery shopping, driving, or paying the bills?

sect2.para: Clients sometimes come to an interview having already explored their symptoms or problems. They likely have guesses about their symptoms or underlying reasons for seeking an assessment assessment , though they may not tell the clinician directly (i. e., “secret questions”). Common secret question themes include reassurance seeking, hope that a diagnosis will (or will not) be given, fear of the future, concerns about expectations and role changes, and guilt, shame, or loss. Exploring the client’s secret questions also allows the clinician to address the possibility that a client may be disappointed by the evaluation outcomes (e. g., receiving a diagnosis when they hoped results would indicate nothing was wrong). When exploring the client’s secret questions, the clinician should use empathy and clinical skills to acknowledge client concerns, educate, and prime clients for potential outcomes. This approach validates the client’s experiences and helps alleviate fears that the clinician will not truly understand the situation. Knowing the client’s secret questions could facilitate person-centered recommendations that may be better received than general recommendations (see Nelson, 2019 for more information on clients’ secret questions). In addition to client’s secret questions, clinicians should be aware that clients may present themselves in a way that confirms their beliefs about the problem. The clinician should listen for cues that the client has researched symptoms and behaviors. Asking directly about what the client thinks is the cause of their problems and if they have any diagnoses in mind can help uncover these types of secret questions.

The clinical interview often starts with a simple question, “What brings you here today?” If a clinician does not inquire further, they may miss important information and neglect to interview in a manner that gets at the root of the referral question. The clinician should avoid social questions, such as “How are you today” or “How was your week,” which may lead clients to provide vague generalizations about their well-being. Some targeted questions that could help clarify the referral question include, “What is going on that led you to make this appointment,” “What made you seek the evaluation at this time,” “What are your goals for our meeting today,” and “When this evaluation is done, what do you hope to learn?” The clinician could also adapt the various referral questions from Table 3.1 to learn more about the client’s motivations for seeking treatment (e. g., “What services are you hoping to access through this evaluation,” “Do you think other things could be contributing to the problem”).
